variant.question: Which of the following answers is true?

options.text: V~1~ < V~MCG~
V~1~ > V~LOF~
V~1~ > V~R~

variant.question: Which of the following answers is true?

options.text: V1 <= VR
V1 < VMCG
V1 > VLOF
V1 > VR

variant.question:
When approaching a wet runway, with the risk of hydroplaning, what technique should the pilot adapt?
 (Note VP = aquaplaning speed)

options.text: Positive touch down, full reverse and brakes as soon as possible.
Positive touch down full reverse and only brakes below VP.
Normal landing, full reverse and brakes at VP.
Smoothest possible touch down, full reverse and only brakes below VP.

variant.question: What does the abbreviation "V~<span>LE~" mean?

options.text: Maximum landing gear extended speed
Minimum level speed
Maximum level speed
Maximum landing gear operating speed

variant.question: The abbreviation V~NE~ means:

options.text: never exceed speed
normal extension speed
normal speed with landing gear extended
maximum speed in level flight

variant.question: For which hydroplaning speed would you use a factor of 9, used in the following formula: (9 × √ tyre pressure)?

options.text: Dynamic hydroplaning
Steam hydroplaning.
Viscous hydroplaning
Reverted rubber hydroplaning.

variant.question: This formula for calculating the dynamic hydroplaning speed distinguishes between rotating and non-rotating tyres. Which of the following statements best describes the most limiting speed for an aircraft operating on a wet runway?

options.text: The hydroplaning speed of non-rotating tyres is lower, because there is a higher risk of hydroplaning immediately following wheel spin-up during touchdown.
Hydroplaning speed depends only on the amount of standing water and tyre rotation, and can be calculated using the aircraft mass multiplied by the amount of standing water.
The hydroplaning speed of rotating tyres is lower, because there is a higher risk of hydroplaning during the roll-out phase.
Hydroplaning speed is lowest for low-pressure rotating tyres and can be calculated using the aircraft mass multiplied by the tyre pressure.

variant.question: The type specific performances associated with contaminated runways are to be found in...

options.text: Part B of the Operations Manual.
Part C of the Operations Manual.
Part D of the Operations Manual.
Part A of the Operations Manual.

variant.question: Is the V~1~ speed on a wet runway higher or lower than on a dry runway?

options.text: Lower, because on a wet runway an aircraft takes longer to stop in the event of an aborted takeoff.
The V1 speed is the same for both runways.
Higher, because on a wet runway an aircraft requires a shorter distance to stop in the event of an aborted takeoff.
Lower, because aircraft can reach higher speeds on wet runways.

variant.question: For which hydroplaning speed would you use a factor of 9?

options.text: Dynamic hydroplaning
Viscous hydroplaning
Reverted rubber hydroplaning
No hydroplaning formula uses a factor of 9

variant.question: Collect snow and forming it into a ball where it keeps its shape as a snowball. This refers to:

options.text: wet snow.
compacted snow.
slush.
dry snow.

variant.question: In the OPS regulations, a runway is considered damp when:

options.text: its surface is not dry, and when surface moisture does not give it a shiny appearance.
it is covered with a film of water of less than 1 mm.
surface moisture gives it a shiny appearance.
it is covered with a film of water of less than 3 mm.

variant.question: Which type of wheel is more sensitive to hydroplaning?

options.text: Non rotating wheels
It is prohibited to operate with rotating wheels on a contaminated surface
Rotating wheels
Rotating and non rotating wheels are equally sensitive

variant.question: When is a runway considered to be contaminated? When:

options.text: More than 25 % of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with wet ice 1.5 mm thick.
Only if the contaminant covers a connected 25 % of the runway surface area (patches of contaminants can add up to more than 25 % of the surface area without effects).
More than 25 % of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with slush equivalent to 2 mm of water.
Less than 25 % of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with water more than 3 mm deep.

variant.question: A contaminated runway means a runway of which more than 25 % of the surface area within the required length and width being used is covered by more than:

options.text: 3 mm of water
5 mm of wet snow
10 mm of wet snow
2 mm of water

variant.question: A Performance Class A turbojet aeroplane is planned to be operated on contaminated runways and on wet runways with suitable performance accountability for the increased stopping distance. For planning purposes, the use of...

options.text: derated take-off thrust is allowed on both types of runways.
reduced take-off thrust is allowed only on contaminated runways.
reduced take-off thrust is allowed on both types of runways.
derated take-off thrust is allowed only on wet runways.

variant.question: Snow that 'sticks to the bottom of a shoe and falls off when the shoe is raised' describes...

options.text: dry snow.
wet snow.
slush.
compacted snow.

variant.question: You are preparing for departure at an airfield with two runways, one is reported as contaminated and the other is reported as wet. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: A derated thrust takeoff is allowed on either runway
A reduced thrust takeoff is only allowed on the contaminated runway
A reduced thrust takeoff is allowed on either runway
A derated thrust takeoff is only allowed on the wet runway

variant.question: The correct description for 'compacted snow' is...

options.text: Snow that has been compacted into a solid mass such that aeroplane tyres, will run on the surface without significant further compaction or rutting of the surface.
It consists of compacted slush with a depth of at least 13 mm.
Snow which, if compacted by hand, will stick together and tend to or form a snowball.
It consists of freshly fallen dry snow with a minimum depth of 50 mm.

variant.question: A runway covered with 4 mm thick water, is said to be:

options.text: contaminated.
flooded.
wet.
damp.

variant.question: For which hydroplaning speed do you use a factor of 9?

options.text: Dynamic.
Reverted Rubber Hydroplaning.
Viscous.
Used only when Anti/Skid is inoperative.

variant.question: Dry snow...

options.text: if compacted by hand to form a snow ball, will fall apart again upon release.
is snow, which has been compressed into a solid mass and resists further compression, and will hold together or break up into lumps if picked up.
if compacted by hand, will stick together and tend to or form a snowball.
will splatter if stepped on forcefully.

variant.question: What is the type of saturated snow, which when hit in a heel-to-toe, slap-down manner, will splatter around?

options.text: slush
dry snow
wet snow
compacted snow

variant.question: What of the following statements is true regarding landing on a contaminated runway, in comparison to a dry runway?

options.text: The increased friction of a contaminated surface has less influence than the reduced efficiency of the brakes, resulting in a longer landing compared to a dry surface.
The reduced friction will allow us to reduce thrust faster, resulting in a shorter landing distance than on a wet runway.
The tyre friction is much greater than in wet conditions, so the landing distance will be greater.
The increased friction is offset by hydroplaning, so the landing distance is approximately the same on a contaminated runway as on a dry one.

variant.question:
Refer to the annex.
A pilot is considering the possibility of having to land on a flooded runway and is evaluating the aircraft configuration and the selection of the landing speeds. Given the following information, choose the lowest (smallest) possible flap setting that would avoid dynamic hydroplaning on landing. 
Take-off Mass: 45000 kg
Tyre pressure: 200 psi

options.text: Flaps 30
Flaps 40
Flaps 25
Flaps 15

variant.question: Some wind limitations may apply in case of contaminated runways. Those limitations are to be found in...

options.text: Part B of the Operations Manual
Part C of the Operations Manual
Part D of the Operations Manual
Part A of the Operations Manual

variant.question: A crew selects a CI of 0. What does it mean?

options.text: Maximum range airspeed.
Maximum cruising airspeed.
Minimum airspeed.
Minimum range airspeed.

variant.question: A runway is considered to be contaminated when its surface is covered with compacted snow or ice more than:
Aircraft-type-specific procedures for take-off and landing on contaminated runways can be found in the Operations Manual _____, under Normal procedures.

options.text: Part B
Part D
Part C
Part A

variant.question:
Under Regulations, a runway is considered wet when:
 
1. It is covered with a quantity of water or loose or slushy snow less than or equal to the equivalent of 3 mm of water.
2. The amount of surface moisture is sufficient to modify its colour but does not give it a shiny appearance.
3. The amount of surface moisture is sufficient to make it reflective, but does not create large stagnant sheets of water.
4. It bears stagnant sheets of water.
 
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
4 mm of rain is covering a runway. The runway is:

options.text: contaminated
flooded
wet
damp

variant.question: When approaching a wet runway in stormy conditions:

options.text: Increased approach speed
Full anti-skid braking with a firm touchdown.
Decreased approach speed
A steeper approach path

variant.question:
In accordance to EASA AIR OPS, a runway is considered wet when:
1) it is covered with a quantity of water or loose or slushy snow less than or equal to the equivalent of 3 mm of water.
2) the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to modify its colour but does not give it a shiny appearance.
3) the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to make it reflective, but does not create large stagnant sheets of water.
4) it bears stagnant sheets of water.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
Where are the procedures associated with take-off and landing on contaminated runways found?

options.text: Part B of the Operations Manual
Part C of the Operations Manual
Part A of the Operations Manual
Part D of the Operations Manual

variant.question: Normal procedures associated with take-off and landing on contaminated runways are to be found in...

options.text: Part B of the Operations Manual
Part A of the Operations Manual
Part D of the Operations Manual
Part C of the Operations Manual

variant.question: The ICAO definition of a damp runway is:

options.text: where the runway surface is not dry, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance
where the runway surface is not dry although the moisture on it gives it a shiny appearance
where the runway surface is wet and the moisture on it gives a shiny appearance
where the runway surface is wet, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance

variant.question:
In the OPS regulations, a runway is considered wet when:1. it is covered with a quantity of water or loose or slushy snow less than or equal to the equivalent of 3 mm of water. 
 2. the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to modify its colour but does not give it a shiny appearance. 
 3. the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to make it reflective, but does not create large stagnant sheets of water. 
 4. it bears stagnant sheets of water.The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
A runway is covered over the total length with 5 mm depth of wet ice. In terms of runway contamination, ‘’wet ice’’ is...

options.text: ice with water on top of it or ice that is melting.
water that has frozen or compacted snow that has transitioned into ice in cold and dry conditions.
ice crystals formed from airborne moisture on a surface on a surface whose temperature is at or below freezing.
snow that has been compacted into a solid mass.

variant.question: A runway is covered with a layer of wet ice, 5 mm thick, and along the total runway length. What is the correct definition of such contamination (wet ice)?

options.text: Ice with water on top of it or ice that is melting.
Snow that is so water-saturated that water will drain from it when a handful is picked up or will splatter if stepped on forcefully.
Snow that has been compacted into a solid mass.
Water that has frozen or compacted snow that has transitioned into ice in cold and dry conditions.

variant.question: In accordance to EASA AIR OPS and ICAO, a runway is referred to as contaminated when more than 25% of the required runway surface is covered with the one of the following elements: - A water film sufficiently thick to give a shiny appearance to the runway - A water film or loose or slushy snow equivalent to more than 3 mm of water - Compacted snow (a solid mass which may not be compacted further) - Ice, including wet ice - Moist grass The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
